title: Witness Under Pressure and Expansion Through Disruption
teaser: The gospel advances not in spite of pressure, but often through it

modules.passage: In those days when the number of disciples was increasing, the Hellenistic Jews among them complained against the Hebraic Jews because their widows were being overlooked in the daily distribution of food. So the Twelve gathered all the disciples together and said, 'It would not be right for us to neglect the ministry of the word of God in order to wait on tables. Brothers and sisters, choose seven men from among you who are known to be full of the Spirit and wisdom. We will turn this responsibility over to them and will give our attention to prayer and the ministry of the word.' This proposal pleased the whole group. They chose Stephen, a man full of faith and of the Holy Spirit; also Philip, Procorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicolas from Antioch, a convert to Judaism. They presented these men to the apostles, who prayed and laid their hands on them. So the word of God spread. The number of disciples in Jerusalem increased rapidly, and a large number of priests became obedient to the faith.

modules.content:
Up to this point, Acts has shown us a church growing in favor, power, and clarity. But growth always brings strain. In Acts 6-12, the church enters a new phase where internal tension, violent opposition, and geographic scattering all converge at once.

What looks like disruption becomes expansion.
What looks like loss becomes multiplication.
What looks like chaos becomes mission.

This week traces one of the most important transitions in the entire book of Acts. The church moves from being a Jerusalem-centered movement led almost exclusively by the apostles into a Spirit-driven mission that cannot be contained by geography, culture, or fear.

These chapters show us that the gospel does not advance in spite of pressure, but often through it.
modules.heading: Setting the Stage: What Happens in Acts 6-12

modules.content:
The first major problem in the church is not persecution, but inequity. Greek-speaking widows are being overlooked in the daily distribution of food. This is not a small logistical issue. In a community where shared resources are a core witness, neglect threatens the church's integrity.

The apostles respond wisely. They do not deny the problem or centralize more power. Instead, they empower others, appointing seven Spirit-filled leaders to serve.
modules.heading: Internal Tension and Shared Leadership (Acts 6)

modules.content:
What makes Stephen's speech remarkable is what it does not do. He never tries to defend himself. He does not plead for mercy or attempt to soften the charges. Instead, he retells Israel's entire story, from Abraham to Solomon.

Stephen's point is not historical trivia. It is theological diagnosis. He shows that God has always worked outside fixed religious structures. God called Abraham before there was a temple. God met Moses in the wilderness, not in Jerusalem. God traveled with His people long before buildings and institutions were established.

At the same time, Stephen exposes a painful pattern. Israel repeatedly resists God's messengers. Joseph is rejected by his brothers. Moses is resisted by the people he delivers. The prophets are ignored, persecuted, and killed.

Stephen is saying something dangerous: You are doing now what your ancestors always did.

His speech reaches its climax when he lifts his eyes and sees Jesus standing at the right hand of God. Not seated in distant authority, but standing, attentive, alive, reigning. That vision seals his fate.
modules.heading: Stephen's Witness and Martyrdom (Acts 7)

modules.content:
Stephen's death ignites widespread persecution. Believers are forced to flee Jerusalem. But Acts 8 makes something clear: The gospel is not fragile. Wherever believers go, they carry the message with them. Scattering does not silence the church. It multiplies it.

Philip steps into Samaria, a region long divided from Jerusalem by centuries of ethnic hostility, theological disagreement, and social exclusion. Jews and Samaritans avoided each other. Their histories were tangled with resentment. And yet, Samaritans believe. They receive the Holy Spirit. God confirms their inclusion unmistakably.

Then the Spirit shifts Philip again, this time to a desert road. There he meets an Ethiopian official. Powerful, educated, influential, yet religiously excluded because of his status. Philip explains Scripture through Jesus. The Ethiopian believes. He is baptized immediately. No delay. No barrier. No gatekeeping.
modules.heading: Scattering That Spreads the Gospel (Acts 8)

modules.content:
Acts 10 brings a quiet but seismic shift. Peter receives a vision that dismantles deeply ingrained categories of clean and unclean. What Peter has always understood as obedience, God now challenges.

At the same time, a Gentile named Cornelius receives his own vision. God is orchestrating both sides of the encounter. When Peter preaches in Cornelius's house, the Holy Spirit falls before baptism. Before permission. Before approval. God makes His position clear. The Spirit is not waiting for consensus.

This moment matters because: The church crosses ethnic boundaries officially; God redefines belonging from the inside out; Obedience now requires unlearning as much as learning.

Acts 11 shows the church wrestling honestly with this change. There is confusion. Debate. Fear of losing identity. But ultimately, they recognize God's hand at work: 'So then, even to Gentiles God has granted repentance that leads to life.'
modules.heading: Peter and the Expanding Vision of God's People (Acts 10-11)

modules.content:
Acts 12 brings the most direct state-sponsored violence the church has faced so far. Herod arrests leaders. James is executed. Peter is imprisoned under heavy guard. This is not rumor or threat. It is reality.

And yet, the church responds with prayer. Not strategy. Not protest. Prayer.

God intervenes in unexpected ways. An angel frees Peter from prison while the guards remain unaware. Meanwhile, the church is so stunned by answered prayer that they struggle to believe it when Peter appears at the door. Herod's story ends in stark contrast. His pride leads to sudden downfall.
modules.heading: Persecution Intensifies and God Intervenes (Acts 12)

modules.content:
The early church learned that following Jesus was not a path of protection, but a path of trust. God did not promise insulation from harm. He promised His presence within it.

Growth may require discomfort. Faithfulness matters more than safety. God often works through what we want to avoid. Witness is both personal and communal.

modules.prompt: Where are you being invited to courage instead of control?

modules.prayerText: Lord Jesus, you stood at the right hand of the Father as Stephen gave his life. You appeared to Saul on the road of persecution. You sent your Spirit to Cornelius before anyone gave permission. Help me trust that you are present in my pressures, active in my disruptions, and faithful through every cost. Give me the courage to witness even when it is inconvenient, to welcome even when it is uncomfortable, and to follow even when the path is unclear. Like Stephen, may I keep my eyes fixed on you. Amen.

modules.usage: The Greek word 'martys' originally meant simply 'witness' - one who testifies to what they have seen or experienced. After Stephen and the early martyrs, the word took on its modern meaning of one who dies for their faith. Our English word 'martyr' comes directly from this Greek term. The shift in meaning reflects how the early church understood that ultimate witness often came through ultimate sacrifice.
